post_text: Out of an abundance of caution, this notice is to inform the community of two cases of COVID-19 at Ninety Six Primary School. On September 3, 2020, two individuals self-reported testing positive for COVID-19. These individuals have been self-quarantining at home awaiting test results and have not been at Ninety Six Primary School. These individuals had close contacts at Edgewood Middle School and Ninety Six High School. Close contacts have not tested positive to date and are being quarantined at home. All of the close contacts have been notified of the situation by the school nurse. All parents of students and district employees, who experience symptoms or receive a positive COVID-19 test are strongly encouraged to seek medical advice from their healthcare provider and should contact the District Office to determine the appropriate return procedure.

There are adults getting upset because the school district will not provide breakfasts and lunches to adults when children are not present at pick-up. Children being present is an United States Department of Agriculture requirement, not a Greenwood School District 52 policy. If children are not present, then we may have adults without children picking up meals for themselves. Children present is the accountability measure put in place by the federal government to make sure children are the ones receiving the meals. This requirement is non-negotiable.

The rule of thumb is as follows: Adults need children present to pick-up meals, but children don’t need adults present to pick-up their own meal.

I’m very sorry for the inconvenience, but our hands are tied.

Greenwood District 52 is proud to announce the addition of Officer Bianca Carroll as SRO. Officer Carroll joins Lt. Mac Boudreau who has served as SRO for Greenwood District 52 for two years. We are extremely proud and honored to have Lt. Boudreau and Officer Carroll. They work daily and tirelessly to keep our schools safe and to build relationships with our students.

Recently, Officer Carroll met with the Bridge Builders Club at Ninety Six Elementary. The focus of the club's meeting was to create an open dialogue between students and the SRO. Ideas on ways to make the school safer, form friends, and prevent bullying were discussed. One of the ideas emerging from the meeting was the placement of an anonymous box in the hall to be used for students to report issues within the school.

Thank you Lt. Bourdreau and Officer Carroll for being a part of our Greenwood District 52 team. Also, many thanks to Chief Porter, the Town of Ninety Six, and the Greenwood District 52 Board of Trustees for the support you have provided partnering with our district to add SROs to our schools.
